text.p: Swedish carmaker Saab Automobile plans two new models -- the 900 and the new 640 to be introduced in 1997 -- and will discontinue the 9000, Saab Auto CEO Robert Hendry told Reuters in an interview on Monday.
"The new 640 is to replace the 9000-model. Saab 640 will together with the 900-series become our two mainstream models," Hendry said.
He added that the 9000-model will be kept in production as long as "it is asked for", but that it will not be replaced by a new version. The Saab 900 will be redone in a couple of years.

"The question of a third and smaller model has been raised, but it is not a top priority. We must make a profit before we make new models," Hendry said. He said previously the company did not expect to break even this year and maybe not next.
Saab will add a diesel engine to its product-line within the next couple of years.

"We do understand the value of being able to offer a diesel engine, especially in markets like France," Hendry said. More than a third of new cars sold in France have diesel engines, compared with less than a quarter in Europe.
